enb_long_title: Twenty-sixth sessions of the Subsidiary Bodies (SB 26) of the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC)
section_title: SECURITY COUNCIL SESSION ON CLIMATE CHANGE:
sentences: On 17 April 2007, the UN Security Council discussed climate change for the first time.
The meeting focused on the impact of climate change on peace and security.

Some delegates, including the G-77/China, raised doubts regarding the Council's role on this issue, suggesting that it was primarily a socioeconomic and/or sustainable development issue that should be addressed by the General Assembly.
However, many others, particularly small island states, welcomed the Council's discussions.
Many speakers urged the UN to give urgent consideration to holding a global summit on climate change.
Participants also discussed the IPCC reports, the upcoming negotiations in Bali in late 2007, and the needs of the most vulnerable countries.

The EU reiterated its recent unilateral commitment to reduce its greenhouse gas emissions by 20% by 2020 compared with 1990 levels, and to increase this to 30% if other developed countries took similar steps.
